document.title: Wisconsin's Model Academic Standards for Social Studies

5108E520DFE8013100FB68A86D17958E.description: Describe instances of cooperation and interdependence among individuals, groups, and nations, such as helping others in famines and disasters

51089420DFE8013100FA68A86D17958E.description: Describe how differences in cultures may lead to understanding or misunderstanding among people

51083A30DFE8013100F968A86D17958E.description: Investigate and explain similarities and differences in ways that cultures meet human needs

5107FD10DFE8013100F868A86D17958E.description: Give examples of important contributions made by Wisconsin citizens, United States citizens, and world citizens

5107BCC0DFE8013100F768A86D17958E.description: Give examples and explain how language, stories, folk tales, music, and other artistic creations are expressions of culture and how they convey knowledge of other peoples and cultures

51077B10DFE8013100F668A86D17958E.description: Give examples and explain how the media may influence opinions, choices, and decisions

51073C10DFE8013100F568A86D17958E.description: Explain how people learn about others who are different from themselves

5106FAD0DFE8013100F468A86D17958E.description: Describe and distinguish among the values and beliefs of different groups and institutions

5106B4E0DFE8013100F368A86D17958E.description: Explain the reasons why individuals respond in different ways to a particular event and the ways in which interactions among individuals influence behavior

510660B0DFE8013100F268A86D17958E.description: Give examples of group and institutional influences such as laws, rules, and peer pressure on people, events, and culture

51061B50DFE8013100F168A86D17958E.description: Identify and describe institutions such as school, church, police, and family and describe their contributions to the well being of the community, state, nation, and global society

5105D570DFE8013100F068A86D17958E.description: Describe the ways in which ethnic cultures influence the daily lives of people

51057550DFE8013100EF68A86D17958E.description: Describe how families are alike and different, comparing characteristics such as size, hobbies, celebrations, where families live, and how they make a living

51053160DFE8013100EE68A86D17958E.description: Explain the influence of factors such as family, neighborhood, personal interests, language, likes and dislikes, and accomplishments on individual identity and development

5104E910DFE8013100ED68A86D17958E.description: Explain the influence of prior knowledge, motivation, capabilities, personal interests, and other factors on individual learning

51049600DFE8013100EC68A86D17958E.description: Students in Wisconsin will learn about the behavioral sciences by exploring concepts from the discipline of sociology, the study of the interactions among individuals, groups, and institutions; the discipline of psychology, the study of factors that influence individual identity and learning; and the discipline of anthropology, the study of cultures in various times and settings.

51044B10DFE8013100EB68A86D17958E.description: The Behavioral Sciences: Individuals, Institutions, and Society

5103FEF0DFE8013100EA68A86D17958E.description: Describe how personal economic decisions, such as deciding what to buy, what to recycle, or how much to contribute to people in need, can affect the lives of people in Wisconsin, the United States, and the world

5103A8A0DFE8013100E968A86D17958E.description: Identify the economic roles of various institutions, including households, businesses, and government

51032C90DFE8013100E868A86D17958E.description: Distinguish between private goods and services (for example, the family car or a local restaurant) and public goods and services (for example, the interstate highway system or the United States Postal Service)

51029680DFE8013100E768A86D17958E.description: Give examples to explain how businesses and industry depend upon workers with specialized skills to make production more efficient

51024290DFE8013100E668A86D17958E.description: Identify local goods and services that are part of the global economy and explain their use in Wisconsin

510200B0DFE8013100E568A86D17958E.description: Identify situations requiring an allocation of limited economic resources and appraise the opportunity cost (for example, spending one's allowance on a movie will mean less money saved for a new video game)

5101BDE0DFE8013100E468A86D17958E.description: Describe and explain of the role of money, banking, and savings in everyday life

51017960DFE8013100E368A86D17958E.description: Students in Wisconsin will learn about production, distribution, exchange, and consumption so that they can make informed economic decisions.

5100D880DFE8013100E168A86D17958E.description: Locate, organize, and use relevant information to understand an issue in the classroom or school, while taking into account the viewpoints and interests of different groups and individuals

510095F0DFE8013100E068A86D17958E.description: Explain how various forms of civic action such as running for political office, voting, signing an initiative, and speaking at hearings, can contribute to the well-being of the community

51005290DFE8013100DF68A86D17958E.description: Explain the basic purpose of government in American society, recognizing the three levels of government

51000EA0DFE8013100DE68A86D17958E.description: Explain how families, schools, and other groups develop, enforce, and change rules of behavior and explain how various behaviors promote or hinder cooperation

50FFCB80DFE8013100DD68A86D17958E.description: Identify the documents, such as the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution, and the Bill of Rights, in which the rights of citizens in our country are guaranteed.

50FF86D0DFE8013100DC68A86D17958E.description: Identify and explain the individual's responsibilities to family, peers, and the community, including the need for civility and respect for diversity

50FF32E0DFE8013100DB68A86D17958E.description: Students in Wisconsin will learn about political science and acquire the knowledge of political systems necessary for developing individual civic responsibility by studying the history and contemporary uses of power, authority, and governance.

50FEDFF0DFE8013100DA68A86D17958E.description: Political Science and Citizenship: Power, Authority, Governance, and Responsibility

50FE9140DFE8013100D968A86D17958E.description: Explain the history, culture, tribal sovereignty, and current status of the American Indian tribes and bands in Wisconsin

50FE46D0DFE8013100D868A86D17958E.description: Describe examples of cooperation and interdependence among individuals, groups, and nations

50FE0440DFE8013100D768A86D17958E.description: Compare past and present technologies related to energy, transportation, and communications and describe the effects of technological change, either beneficial or harmful, on people and the environment

50FDC500DFE8013100D668A86D17958E.description: Identify and describe important events and famous people in Wisconsin and United States history

50FD7FE0DFE8013100D568A86D17958E.description: Explain the significance of national and state holidays, such as Independence Day and Martin Luther King, Jr. Day, and national and state symbols, such as the United States flag and the state flags

50FD2C70DFE8013100D468A86D17958E.description: Identify the historical background and meaning of important political values such as freedom, democracy, and justice

50FCC5C0DFE8013100D368A86D17958E.description: Compare and contrast changes in contemporary life with life in the past by looking at social, economic, political, and cultural roles played by individuals and groups

50FC7790DFE8013100D268A86D17958E.description: Examine biographies, stories, narratives, and folk tales to understand the lives of ordinary and extraordinary people, place them in time and context, and explain their relationship to important historical events

50FC3870DFE8013100D168A86D17958E.description: Use a timeline to select, organize, and sequence information describing eras in history

50FBF270DFE8013100D068A86D17958E.description: Identify and examine various sources of information that are used for constructing an understanding of the past, such as artifacts, documents, letters, diaries, maps, textbooks, photos, paintings, architecture, oral presentations, graphs, and charts

50FB9BC0DFE8013100CF68A86D17958E.description: Students in Wisconsin will learn about the history of Wisconsin, the United States, and the world, examining change and continuity over time in order to develop historical perspective, explain historical relationships, and analyze issues that affect the present and the future.

50FAFC30DFE8013100CD68A86D17958E.description: Give examples to show how scientific and technological knowledge has led to environmental changes, such as pollution prevention measures, air-conditioning, and solar heating

50FAB0A0DFE8013100CC68A86D17958E.description: Identify major changes in the local community that have been caused by human beings, such as a construction project, a new highway, a building torn down, or a fire; discuss reasons for these changes; and explain their probable effects on the community and the environment

50FA6800DFE8013100CB68A86D17958E.description: Identify connections between the local community and other places in Wisconsin, the United States, and the world

50FA1E30DFE8013100CA68A86D17958E.description: Identify and distinguish between predictable environmental changes, such as weather patterns and seasons, and unpredictable changes, such as floods and droughts, and describe the social and economic effects of these changes

50F9D500DFE8013100C968A86D17958E.description: Use atlases, databases, grid systems, charts, graphs, and maps to gather information about the local community, Wisconsin, the United States, and the world

50F96FF0DFE8013100C868A86D17958E.description: Describe and give examples of ways in which people interact with the physical environment, including use of land, location of communities, methods of construction, and design of shelters

50F92400DFE8013100C768A86D17958E.description: Construct a map of the world from memory, showing the location of major land masses, bodies of water, and mountain ranges

50F8D8B0DFE8013100C668A86D17958E.description: Locate on a map or globe physical features such as continents, oceans, mountain ranges, and land forms, natural features such as resources, flora, and fauna; and human features such as cities, states, and national borders

50F88DB0DFE8013100C568A86D17958E.description: Use reference points, latitude and longitude, direction, size, shape, and scale to locate positions on various representations of the earth's surface

50F84140DFE8013100C468A86D17958E.description: Students in Wisconsin will learn about geography through the study of the relationships among people, places, and environments.
